author: Reuters
description: Mexico's government welcomed the upcoming renegotiation
title: Trump Administration to Renegotiate NAFTA Agreement With Canada and Mexico

author: Ben Dummett
description: Mexico’s Grupo Lala has emerged as the lead bidder for Stonyfield Farm Inc., the well-known U.S. maker of organic yogurt.
title: Mexico’s Grupo Lala Is Lead Bidder for Danone’s Stonyfield Farm

author: Anthony Harrup
description: A fast-approaching deadline in a longstanding dispute with Mexico over sugar could be a harbinger of how broader Nafta talks could play out.
title: How U.S. Settles Sugar Dispute With Mexico Could Signal Nafta Intent

author: The Economist
description: The campaigner for Mexico’s disappeared was 50
title: Obituary: Miriam Rodríguez Martínez died on May 10th

author: Ana Swanson, Ana Swanson
description: Negotiations with Canada and Mexico begin as soon as Aug. 16, the administration said.
title: Trump administration formally launches NAFTA renegotiation

author: Martin Rogers
description: Lightweight from Mexico trying to prove he has "exceptional ability" in Saturday bout
title: Boxer Ray Beltran fights for title shot and green card

author: Patrick Gillespie
description: The Trump administration sent a letter to Congress which officially started a 90-day consultation period required before NAFTA negotiations with Canada and Mexico can begin.
title: Trump pulls trigger for NAFTA talks

author: By Simon Holmes For Mailonline
description: The world's heaviest man, Juan Pedro Franco, has been discharged from a hospital in western Mexico after undergoing stomach surgery to help him lose weight.
title: World's fattest man released from hospital after stomach surgery

author: David Lawder
description: The Trump administration on Thursday set the clock ticking toward a mid-August start of renegotiations of the North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico to try to win better terms for U.S. workers and manufacturers.
title: Trump administration starts countdown to NAFTA talks in mid-August

description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. (AP) — The U.S. Coast Guard unloaded cocaine in South Florida worth nearly $500 million from 20 separate seizures in the eastern Pacific Ocean. Coast Guard officials said in a news release Thursday the seizures totaled about 18.5 tons (about 18.8 metric tons) of cocaine. The recently seized drugs were brought to Port Everglades by the cutter Hamilton. Authorities say the cocaine was intercepted along the Central and South American coasts by Coast Guard cutters and a Royal Canadian Navy ship sailing with a Coast Guard team aboard. The eastern Pacific is a prime smuggling route for cocaine headed to Mexico, where it is typically brought into the U.S.
title: Coast Guard unloads $500M in cocaine from 20 seizures
